qas.question: When was neo-Gothic popularized by influential figures?

answers.text: during the second quarter of the 19th century

qas.question: In Britain after 1837, what was the Gothic revival known as?
During what years was the High Victorian Gothic period in Britain?
What movement was responsible for the philosophy which led to the revival of Anglo Catholic ideas?
Besides ecclesiastical and civic architecture, what other style of architecture did influential figures of the 19th century prefer to use Victorian Gothic for?

plausible_answers.text: during the second quarter of the 19th century

qas.question: When was neo-Gothic forgotten by influential figures?
What was the Gothic death known as in Britain after 1827?
What year was the High Victorian Gothic period in Africa?
What movement was responsible for the philosophy which led to the end of Anglo Catholic ideas?
What other style of architecture did influential figures of the 14th century prefer to use Victorian Gothic for?

context: In England, partly in response to a philosophy propounded by <a3_0><b8_0>the Oxford Movement<b8_0/><a3_0/> and others associated with the emerging revival of 'high church' or Anglo-Catholic ideas <a0_0><b5_0>during the second quarter of the 19th century<b5_0/><a0_0/>, neo-Gothic began to become promoted by influential establishment figures as the preferred style for ecclesiastical, civic and <a4_0><b9_0>institutional architecture<b9_0/><a4_0/>. The appeal of this Gothic revival (which after 1837, in Britain, is sometimes termed <a1_0><b6_0>Victorian Gothic<b6_0/><a1_0/>), gradually widened to encompass "low church" as well as "high church" clients. This period of more universal appeal, spanning <a2_0><b7_0>1855<b7_0/>–1885<a2_0/>, is known in Britain as High Victorian Gothic.
